reviews.review_msg: CMPT 473 was pretty informative on different software testing fundamentals. Nick does a great job at explaining all topics, and the code is well structured with a pop quiz at the start of class each week. The Assignments were also fun, but can take some time setting up environments. Overall straightforward course and I learnt a lot.

Notes are pretty bare, so go to class (pop quizzes anyways) and jot down what he says. Nick can sometimes be quick to respond via email. Assignments are pretty cool, but can sometimes take some thought. Nick claims that you don't need to memorize, but you clearly need to memorize a bunch of stuff for the final exam. Slight curving applied - B- avg.

Decent course, pop quizzes are annoying and content is a bit boring as it only covers surface level knowledge. The assignments and final exam were relatively reasonable if you go to class. Horrible TAs though with inconsistent grading at the beginning of the semester, don't think they knew the material.

Professor Sumner is a pretty great professor. You will learn a lot of practical knowledge and his explanations are pretty engaging. Only issue is that the assignments are pretty annoying and most of the time spent would be getting the tool of the week to work on a random project rather than working on the actual topic and purpose of the assignment.

Very knowledgeable, experienced, and nice prof who has good advice. But if you miss one lecture you're screwed. His site is not reliable for determining where the class is in lecture slides and his lecture slides are useless for catching up, incessantly asking you questions about key points of the material rather than actually explaining anything.

I am shocked to see that his score is so low. He is an amazing prof, the course was amazing, learnt so much industry level stuff that I usually never expected a course to teach me. Nick is literally one of the best profs I have ever taken, he is easily accessible even out of class, his replying speed is 5-15 minutes.

Very knowledgeable, but should not teach students. Did not grade any quizzes or assignments, and unclear how much anything would worth. Slides are pretty much useless as they don't have any information that can be studied off of, but consist of 'questions'.
avoid this guy

The course is a pretty interesting survey, Sumner really created an awesome set of content. He teaches it super well, explains thoroughly, and really knows his stuff. Quizzes relied on understanding the material, but were not difficult. He goes over answers for quizzes after each, so you know how well you did. He sucked for getting marks back tho.
Easy assignments and exams

attendance pretty much required since u won't know when he'll give a pop quiz. makes false promises of getting our marks back couple of times. assignments are literally "find an open source project and run test on it". at least he's nice and willing to help students on office hours.

Professor Sumner is a nice person, in person. However he dropped communication with his students ASAP. As of writing, it is now three weeks since the final exam, and people are only starting to get their exam grades back. Three weeks after final exam - 45% of marks received. Feeling stressed and ghosted. Do not take.

Out of the 40 courses I've taken, Nick is the worst professor in terms of giving back grades. It's been more than two weeks past the final and still not everyone has their final exam marks. As for regular course marks, we've only recieved 15% of the 70%. Do not take a course with this guy period.
it has been 2 weeks after the final exam and still no marks for anything in the course. very smart prof but if you dislike unorganized profs then DO NOT take this course with him

Very knowledgeable prof and his lectures are good. Assignments are useful. However, its a week and a half after the final and still almost no marks at all which is unacceptable . Going blind into the exam is not good as your not sure what to improve upon or prioritize.

imagine you put time and effort into projects, reports, assignments, quizzes, readings, and exam then the prof don't event care to give u any of ur marks back. if you ok with not getting any marks back ever then take it with him!

Professor Sumner clearly cares about academic integrity, which is good. However he does care about his students and makes false promises. Grades/feedback not recieved even after finals season. Practice questions never published. MIA until 4 hours before exam. C-19 was harsh, which he failed to accommodate student's conditions. Do not take.

what he said and his actions did not match. Although he is very knowledgeable he does not seem to be responsible for the courses he teaches. excepts for students to be on time regardless of any situation however does not do the same himself.
the final was 2 days ago and we still received no marks even though he is a very smart prof, however he is not really responsible.

Don't get me wrong, he was a excellent prof up until the days before the final. But once you talk about marks, man he did not give us anything. Of the 70% of marks we should have gotten back, we only got back 15% at most. Promised marks before the final, but guess what, today was the final and still no marks. Every student went into the exam blind.

He is a very knowledgeable prof, however, throughout the semester whenever we would ask for our marks back, his response would be that we would get it by the weekend. Months later and time for the final but guess what, we are going in blind. The constant lying and not wanting to take responsibility for this class is just disrespectful to students.

Today we have our exam. I have never felt so lost before an exam.. no marks, no knowledge of what grade I have before walking into this exam. apparently he has been mitigating the marking problem. and being a "little delayed" is not a bad problem to have.

if you like a prof with no communication near the end. if you like a prob who gives no marks. if you like a prof who loves what he teaches and someone who is very knowledgable. or if u like a prof who is a master mind at hide and seek.. take it I dare you

even though course material is interesting and he teaches well. but he clutched at the end. MIA from all questions and concerns.... we got not marks back which also hurts my feels. he seems super nice at first but that is how he get u..

April 13 2020 : The day before final and we don't know our marks. Hasn't been responding for the past 5 days. May 2 2020: Still haven't received marks for rest of assignments and quizzes and not everyone has had their final exam marked.

Nick is a great guy who clearly knows a lot about the material he's teaching. However, his teaching style is vague and unclear and his lecture notes are incomplete. The exam is tomorrow and we still haven't received our grades for most of the assignments and quizzes. He does not provide answer keys for any of the quiz/hw so its impossible to learn

Seems like a prof who cares about teaching. However, everything about him is just very vague and confusing. Over simplified lectures and assignments where he just expects us to understand intuitively.....

Typically you'd want your assessments marked before the final day so you have a good idea how you're doing going into the exam. Typically when a professor says he's going to do something, he follows through. Typically you would expect a professor to teach you the course content and not expect you to know it already. Nick, not a typical professor.

His lecture notes are terrible and are mostly comprised of questions. Students who prefer to listen and use posted notes to study will be left out in the dark. Assignments are good for exposure to different automation tools but not very helpful outside that. I will not be taking a class with him again.

Too smart for his class' good. He basically told us at the beginning of the year that it's a 4th year course so we shouldn't expect him to teach us. Assignments took 2 weeks to figure out what he wanted. Marks were promised a week ago but still nothing days before the final.

"global pandamic is not that big of a deal you will get through it and live your life, and cmpt473 is life saving ppl lives rely on this course". answer's the questions for assignments pretty well. gives 7 different answers for the quizzes and says none of them right. final all short answers...

I cannot believe he has so many positive feedbacks. very unclear on the questions he has been asked. and never got anything marked until the day before final. he is "nice" but everything was vague through out the course. S/o to Covid for saving us

never answersQs completely. nothing gets marked until ur final day. "pop quiz"? more like 1 question u might know and one magic trick. other than 4 ppl in front row most people are lost. assignments are just like go find a "good" software and give it to another software and write some unclear report. gl passing unless some sorta pandemic saves u.

Great prof, very knowledgeable, he knows about the Modern software testing techniques. Weekly quizzes from reading materials and lecture slides. Exam worth 30% of grade, hw 20%, quiz 10%, 4 assignments 40% total. Assignments tend to be hard and involve finding open source projects, so make sure to save enough time for it. Class avg: B

No pop quizzes but initially planned to, may do so in the future though so beware. All I can say is he was okay. Lectures were okay but enough to get the idea (lots of self-studying to fully get the content), assignments were tedious but easy so it was okay, quizzes were basically T/F with some short answer but they were okay. Average was a B.
Teaches very well. This class is easier than I thought.

No pop quizzes this term because of COVID. Changed grading scheme during semester (3 "quizzes" of 10%). Unclear assignment grading. Using Nick Sumner's slides. Own slides have mistakes and sounds unsure when teaching. Not accessible during office hours. Recommendation: avoid.

Dr.Cameron's lectures are really boring and hes very unclear about his criterias. The grading feels random and not based on actual criteras he mentions in class. Quizzes every week. Heavy work course. He's very helpful on technical problems however. Great person, not a good prof.

Too free-form course. No real direction and instructions are too vague. Too many assignments and boring readings. Weekly quizzes are based on readings. The books are available though SFU library. But hard to access when everyone in the class reads it at the last moment.
Nice prof. You will have lots of reading in his course (very useful for future).
